comments.commentBody: Thanks for this, Mark. Much needed.  I fear my head will explode if we start the entire 2016 dog-pile now.

Gail, I'm sure you are correct in all you say, and you say it well as always.

I do NOT want to hear about the 2016 presidential race. Not a word. Please.

There is much else that needs your attention more than that distant horse race. We have important things to discuss, and we need you on them.

Alan, it had to happen sometime.  He was my avatar pick, too. I see you took his Wikipedia photo but I was going to use one from his famous role. Now the only question is who will do the reveal and write-up?
So you gave Bush, who was also just one man on duty when 9/11 hit, a pass, too, right?

The secure knowledge that no child ever truly survives a parent's suicide has kept me taking antidepressants for years.  I think an exception might be made, though, for an elderly parent facing years of pain and disability.

R,

Many of the comments that you (and I) object to are not from the Left.
The start of a new cold war? Makes one wonder how Obama will deal with the new regime in Iran.

Last time the world walked away from a bully, 6 million+ people died in camps.

It takes far more courage to look a bully in the eye and say we are not afraid. Obama chickened out.

Completely wrong tactic by Obama.   Go over there and without a TelePrompTer, look him in the eye to let him know ow upset you are.  This was a "tear down this wall" moment and he blew it.  Putin and China must be laughing.  What's next?  Boycotting the 2014 Olympics to show your "disappointment"?  Terrible decision!
Let the kid alone. Who cares? Mr. President distances himself from the populace as his second term moves on / stretches out.
Ronald Reagan was the one who called for tearing down the Berlin War and his policy was probably instrumental in causing the Eastern Bloc and USSR to break up.
Gosh, I thought W Bush was clueless but this guy is making him look like Ronald Reagan.
An extraordinary overstatement.
Now Mr. Media Man, going back to the last (s)election; who would you say is the "Isolationist", Obama, or the GOP candidate you labelled simply as a "Libertarian"?
Reagan met with Russian and Eastern European adversaries.  Obama walks away.  How does that make the latter a Republican?
Do we want to copy Australia?  Is that a model to aspire to?

John you should really learn about the yakka.

http://www.bobinoz.com/blog/5972/the-cost-of-living-australia-and-the-us...

The bottom line is that Americans have to work about 50% longer than Australians to buy the same stuff.
It will never happen here.

If Australia can afford to pay its workers a living wage and provide universal health care (which gets health care off the backs of businesses), why can’t the US do the same? And why should taxpayers subsidize companies like Wal-Mart by providing its workers with health care, food stamps, and housing assistance when the six heirs of the Walton family own wealth equal to that of the bottom 40 percent of America?

The minimum wage in Australia is $16.37 (roughly $15.00 USD), while their unemployment rate is only 5.7 percent.

Minimum wage rates for Australian workers:
$16.37 – adults
$16.00 – 20 years of age
$13.51 – 19 years of age
$11.18 – 18 years of age
$9.46 – 17 years of age
$7.74 – 16 years of age
$6.03 – under 16 years of age

http://www.fairwork.gov.au/pay/national-minimum-wage/Pages/default.aspx

Part-time and temp workers receive 24 percent in cash compensation in lieu of benefits. Full-time workers receive 10 sick days, 20 vacation days, and 10 or more paid holidays.

Fair Work, Fair Pay: Lessons From Australia
http://truth-out.org/opinion/item/5601

“The real difference between the two countries appears in company profits. American companies make far more in profits than Australian companies. Over the past ten years, the profits of corporations and proprietors have amounted to an average of 20.4 percent of America’s national income. The equivalent figure in Australia is 12.7 percent.

“It’s hard to make super-sized profits when you have to pay a living wage.”

For many who've said what you say, reality takes this choice away.  I have no real idea whether my parents would have considered suicide, but one suffered a stroke and the other developed Parkinsonism;  both lost their capacity to follow through if in fact they'd wanted to.  My mother did become unable to eat and drink, and we don't know for sure, but suspect that there was an element of volition in that.

"Economics" as you call it does not exist in a vacuum, as if it were some kind of natural law.  The rights of business owners should not trump the rights of workers to collectively organize -- or the rights of voters to elect representatives to enact legislation.  We live in a country of laws, not only of money, controlled primarily by those who happen to have the most.
It's never too late to hear from you, rpsmith.

Ryan,

If you choose a prior blog post at random, and check out the comments, you will inevitably see comments left re one puzzle even after the next puzzle has gone up on the web site. It REALLY is never too late to leave a comment, because some people download puzzles for later solving, or solve oldies through the archives.

Nothing wrong with posting them on the next day's blog as well! But if you re-posted your remarks about the Wednesday puzzle over on the Wednesday blog, I guarantee someone will read them there.

Heck, I posted a comment today on an April blog post!

-- Mayhave Takenittoo Far
Thank you for the support, Deadline and MTF. I'll be sure to take your words under advisement for the future.

I arrived home too late to post about our Wednesday puzzle, which was smooth and simple (though I continue to be plagued by one-square-wrong outings). It seems paradoxical how a theme so well-established could be presented with a TWIST... but anyway. (OOH, I am suddenly reminded of a delightful joke: Charles Dickens walks into a bar and orders a martini. The bartender says, "Olive, or twist?")

With regards to the Thursday, I was quite impressed. For me, it seemed like a weekend offering -- abundant misdirection, as well as the assortment of intimidating one-letter clues, which took a while to catch on to (the FISHHOOK didn't do its job, I guess).

Deb's point about the violent undercurrents of this crossword opened my own eyes to the deep-seated, somewhat ALARMing malevolence permeating our grid: I can picture guns FIRING, AXES being swung (resulting, no doubt, in CLEAN CUTs), helpless victims being SMUSHed and STEPped ON (perhaps via the use of a VOODOO doll)... even the musical note is SHARP! Heavens, I've worked myself into such a frenzy, I'm beginning to fear some noir-ish villain may leap forth from the puzzle to ASSAssiNaTE me! Oh, well -- if Honest Abe can deliver my EULOGY, things wouldn't seem that bad, all TOLD.

As the president said Col Putin formerly an officer in the KGB is a cold warrior still stuck in that period. The best the US can do at this juncture in the relationship between the 2 countries is to wait Putin out.

You clearly don't understand anything about this subject.

The Chinese visit was not a state visit, so there was no expectation that anyone other than the President -- who went out of his way to meet -- would attend; Mrs. Obama attending a graduation is an important thing, we don't want the President's family to be completely swept aside.

As for meeting Putin, Ireland already demonstrated how pointless a meeting with him could be. Putin's been rounding up artists, political critics, and gays, and expropriating private property. I presume you're unaware of the Magnitsky story, the Russian lawyer who was imprisoned and effectively killed for having the temerity to prove that the Russian government was stealing the property of his client, a British investor.

The White House did the right thing.
Russia is in no way a "failed" Eastern European state, as any Georgian can tell you.
On what possible basis could you assert that "President Putin has won the hearts and minds of most Americans"?
If anything, Putin is HUGELY relieved!

"I am short, round and old and enjoying life."
Best sentence I've read all day.
Thanks!

You've described me, exactly.  I am actually fairly comfortable walking into a room and forgetting why I am there--as you say, I have done this all my life. I have always remembered names, though--names and numbers.  It does bother me not to remember names. I am not yet retired and as a teacher, I not only don't remember names, I give my students new ones, depending on what they look like.  Anyway, I'm glad one or two things are new to me or I would wonder why everyone else is so bothered.

"Fear rules America today."

Brother, you've got that right!
